Burcha'*, Z. paalb `Catalysis Research Group, Chemistry Department, University of Reading, Whiteknights, Reading, RG6 2AD, UK nstitute of Isotopes of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, P.O. Box 77, Budapest, H-1525, Hungary (Received 18 October 1993; revised 11 February 1994; accepted 11 February 1994) Abstract Probe molecules can be used to complement surface characterisation techniques for elucidating the nature of possible active sites in supported metal catalysts. 2,24methylbutane (neohexane) is eminently suitable for this purpose because it combines an isobutyl and an ethyl group, representing two archetypes for hydrocarbon reactions on metal catalysts. In this review a survey is given of hydrogendeuterium exchange, hydrogenolysis, and isomerization of 2,2-dimethylbutane mainly on Group 810 metals, copper, and rhenium, as well as on their various alloys. Hydrogen-deuterium exchange results are presented, and interpretations in terms of factors such as different surface morphologies are considered. For 2,2-dimethylbutane, hydrogenolysis is the main reaction on most catalysts. Isomerization is restricted to platinum, palladium, and to some extent to iridium and nickel. The relative importance of isomerisation versus hydrogenolysis has been examined and it is shown that this is critically dependent on a number of factors, such as the dispersion of the metal, alloy formation, nonmetallic promoters, etc. The patterns of hydrogenolysis products can also be very informative because of the relationship between the observed product and the mode of adsorption of the 2,2-dimethylbutane molecule on different types of surface site. The use of 2,2-dimethylbutane to probe the surface composition of bimetallic particles has been discussed and the factors which influence the product distribution have been examined. The effect of non-metallic additives (water and chlorine) on the ratio of hydrogenolysis-to-isomerization is discussed and the possible important role of the metalsupport interface (`adlineation sites') is pointed out. Metal-hydrocarbon interactions in catalysis; the importance of using probe molecules Since the introduction of the concept of the active site by H.S. Taylor [ 1 ], there have been many attempts to identify and describe active sites on catalyst surfaces. Various methods have been used to this end, including controlled modification of the catalyst surface (e.g., by alloying the active metal with a nominally inert additive [2] ) and/or by the use of different surface science (basically ultra high vacuum) techniques. The latter methods can only occasionally be used as in situ characterisation methods and, moreover, since the introduction of the reactants may very probably change the structure and properties of the catalyst surface [3,4], there is always a considerable doubt about the applicability of such methods to real catalysts. The need to develop genuine in situ techniques for characterising metal surfaces under normal operating conditions extends beyond the purely fundamental interest in active sites. For example, it would be very valuable if methods were available which could be used to monitor changes in the nature of metal catalysts during activation (calcination, reduction), regeneration, or redispersion, all of which are treatments used on real catalysts during their normal working lives. One possible approach to this problem is to use probe molecules, or probe reactions. In principle, reactant molecules provide the most sensitive and specific probe of the surface chemistry of an active site since in the course of their adsorption, reaction and desorption, they must have been associated with the active site. If we are able to interrogate these molecules after their sojourn on the catalyst we may be able to obtain almost direct information about the nature of the active catalyst surface, as far as its catalytic properties are concerned. The exact identification of the active sites as atoms or group of atoms in a certain chemical state and/or geometry still remains an open question. As part of an on-going research programme in the laboratories of both the authors [ 3,5 ] on the characterisation of metal catalysts for hydrocarbon reactions (reforming catalysts) we have begun to attempt to utilise probe reactions to monitor changes R. Burch, Z. Padl /Applied Catalysis A: General 114 (1994) 9-33 11 in the surface chemistry of platinum and Pt/Re reforming catalysts during and after the oxychlorination treatment used industrially to revitalise these catalysts. As a result of this research it has become apparent that some of the existing views on the types of active site required for hydrocarbon reactions (skeletal rearrangements and hydrogenolysis) may be incomplete. The detailed experimental evidence to support this statement will be published elsewhere. However, in the present paper we address the more general question of the specific use of 2,2-dimethylbutane (neohexane) as a probe reactant of the surface chemistry of metallic catalysts. Metal catalyzed hydrocarbon reactions include dehydrogenation, hydrogenolysis, and isomerisation, and, provided the structure of the molecules permit it, cyclization to five-membered cyclopentane rings or to six-membered aromatic cycles is also possible [ 5 ] . The formation and opening of cyclopentane-type structures may represent one of the routes to skeletal isomers [6]. These represent a host of various reaction routes, all, with the exception of dehydrogenation, involving the rupture (and/or formation) of C-C bonds (so-called `skeletal reactions'). Ponec [ 2 ] classified the metal-hydrocarbon interactions to be (i) 2C (interaction of two neighbouring C atoms with the catalyst); (ii) 3C (interaction of the first and the last C atoms in a C3 chain fragment with the catalyst); and (iii) 5C (interaction of a five C-atom molecular fragment with the catalyst). It is obvious, that (iii) leads to so-called CS-cyclic reactions [6] whereas (i) can lead to hydrogenolysis and (ii) to either hydrogenolysis or to `bond-shift type' [7] (or `C3cyclic') [ 2 ] isomerisation. One may decide to select a model compound for which all variations are possible (e.g., n-hexane); however, if one intends to deliberately keep down the number of possible transformations, it is better to select a model hydrocarbon with limited reaction pathways. In this way, the possible role of different types of metal-hydrocarbon interaction can be assessed. Obviously, different types of metal-hydrocarbon interactions will be favoured by different reactant structures. Foger and Anderson proposed two basic modes of interaction between a hydrocarbon and a catalytically active metal surface: a `CZunit mode' and an `iso-unit mode' reaction. They called the simplest molecules whose structure only permitted one or the other type of reaction `archetypes' [ 8] . Hydrogen-deuterium exchange of 2,2-dimethylbutane over metals H-D exchange represents a reaction involving the breaking and formation of CH bonds only. Since all skeletal reactions are usually preceded by loss of one or more H atoms from the reacting alkane, the study of the exchange reaction may be useful to elucidate their initial and final steps. Single exchange means the breaking and re-formation of one C-H bond, whereas multiple exchange involves several such elementary actions during one sojourn of the molecule on the surface. The propagation of multiple exchange involves usually repeated a 1i interactions [ 12] and a quaternary C atom presents an effective blocking to all of the H atoms being exchanged. That is the reason why `multiple' exchange in 2,2-dimethylbutane usually means the incorporation of up to 5 D atoms in its ethyl group. The exchange over nickel film at 0 leads to 98% monodeuterated product together with 2% d2. A platinum film at 20 resulted in 67% dl and 16% d3 product, palladium at 85 gave 31 % d, and 57% d5 product [ 13 ] . The percentage of other deuterated products was small, the maximum number of deuterium atoms being 5 in one neohexane molecule. These authors also studied the deuterium content of deuterolysis of 1,1,3-trimethylcyclopentane. The deuterium distribution was shifted toward more d2-d5 between 116 and 200 over Pt-A1203 with 2 to 4% d6 product [ 14], the overall conversion being increased simultaneously from 4 to 18%. Skeletal reactions of 2,2-dimethylbutane Csicsery and Pines [ 18 ] studied the conversion of neohexane over an `acid-free' chromia-alumina catalyst. The main products at 14% conversion were ethane plus ethene, isobutene and 3,3-dimethylbutene-1 (with selectivities of 25, 21 and 22%, respectively). The total isomerisation selectivity was about 6%, including about 0.5% dimethylbutene and 5% 2-methylpentene. These authors have formulated the `C3 cyclic' skeletal isomerisation pathway prior to the postulation of the bond shift mechanism over metal catalysts, based, mainly on the presence of ca. 0.1% 1,1,2trimethylcyclopropane in the product. Earlier studies of reactions of alkane - including also 2,2-dimethylbutane over supported metal catalysts were discussed in terms of the bifunctional mechanism attributing skeletal isomerisation to acidic centres [ 19 ] . The acid catalyzed isomerisation of 2,2-dimethylbutane involves carbocations. Three different methods of kinetic analysis of bifunctional reactions of all five hexane isomers present R. Burch, Z. PadllApplied Catalysis A: General 114 (1994) 9-33 15 simultaneously in a mixture reacting over Pt/A1203 (435, 10.5 bar, HZ/hydrocarbon ratio 20) all gave the highest relative rate constant for the reaction of 2,2 dimethylbutane to 2,3-dimethylbutane (around 4 as compared with constants below unity for methylpentane formation or fragmentation) [20]. This is in agreement with the known fact that the stability of carbenium ions decreases from tertiary toward primary ones [ 19 ] , hence the formation of 2,3-dimethylbutane (involving reaction of a secondary to tertiary carbenium ion) should be favoured. Platinum catalysts supported on various zeolites showed rather high isomerisation selectivities (15 to 98% between 200 and 310) . The amount of isomers was proportional to the acidity of the support and was, therefore, attributed to a dual function effect, i.e., to the combined interaction of metallic and acidic sites [ 21 ] . This may be a satisfactory explanation when 2,3-dimethylbutane was the only isomer formed (over 3% Pt supported on various zeolites); however, mixtures of Pt/Si02 with various zeolites resulted in the formation of other hexane isomers also, including n-hexane which must have involved a metal-catalyzed route [ 21 ] . Recent work in one of our laboratories [22] indicates that other factors, and hence alternative mechanisms, may be important. Thus, as we shall discuss later, apparently small differences in the pretreatment of even alumina-supported platinum catalysts can result in large variations in the selectivity for isomerisation (e.g., from 9 to 72%, see later, Table 9) . It now seems possible that the variation in the acidity may not be directly responsible for the enhanced isomerisation selectivity. An alternative possibility which may cause the observed changes in selectivity can be the presence of some incompletely reduced platinum in the cages of the zeolitic support. The presence of electron-deficient platinum species as shown by the ESCA spectrum of Pt-zeolites [ 21 ] seems to confirm this point. The isomerisation selectivity decreased roughly in the order Pt = Pd Ir > Ni and so did the importance of 1,3 (ay' plus ay) interactions as compared with a/3 interactions, i.e., lower isomerisation selectivities were usually concomitant with enhanced formation of neopentane (see also later). Information obtained from the use of 2,2-dimethylbutane as probe molecule Garin and Maire [ 62 ] suggested that the chemical identity (platinum versus palladium etc.) of the metal catalyst (`the electronic factor') would be most important in determining the direction of reaction of any reactant. Adopting this general theory to 2,2-dimethylbutane, it is easy to realize the actual importance of the nature of the metal in determining the primary interaction. Mainly a/3 type interactions occur with metals like Rh, Ru, Ni, Re. These metals give, consequently, mostly hydrogenolysis products, particularly 2,2-dimethylpropane (neopentane). Using the classification of Foger and Anderson [ 8 ] , `C2-unit' reactions predominate on these catalysts (Table 4) . The product composition obtained from neohexane transformation is a clear indication whether mainly ay or a /3 types of interaction prevail. It is possible sometimes to follow the switch-over of the molecule from one state to the other. The occurrence of ay (or, including also ay', i.e., the `iso-unit' [8]) type interactions is necessary for isomerization reactions: this is possible with platinum, palladium, and, to some extent, iridium and nickel. Hence, a high isomerization selectivity should be accompanied with enhanced ay and ay' type interactions: experiments indicate that the latter produces most of the isomers (Tables 8 and 9). Once the `electronic factor' determined the prevailing interaction, the `geometric factor' was assumed to decide whether degradative or nondegradative reactions (i.e. hydrogenolysis or isomerization) follow [62]. If we define the geometric factor as the actual surrounding of the active centre at the atomic level, including the arrangement of the atoms and also their chemical nature, the experience collected in the present paper would certainly confirm this suggestion. One must not forget the postulation [3,4] that there is no `inert' additive effect, i.e., a different atom included into the matrix of an active catalyst changes the geometric arrangement and the electronic surroundings. One plausible way to change the ratio of individual reactions (isomerization versus hydrogenolysis) is the introduction of additional components. Ions of the catalyst metal itself (such as Pts+ ) may represent one possible additive promoting R. Burch, Z. Padl /Applied Catalysis A: General 114 (1994) 9-33 31 isomerisation. A component with high hydrogenolysis activity (e.g., rhenium) changes not only the type of prevailing interaction but also the ratio of the abovementioned reactions, the extent of which may vary over a wide range [44,45]. Inactive metals (silver, gold), in contrast, decrease the hydrogenolysis and increase the isomerization selectivity with a considerable decrease in the overall activity. The same effect can be achieved by nonmetallic additives, such as carbon (Tables 3 and 10) , sulphur, and also chlorine (Table 11) . Copper has a peculiar effect: it enhances hydrogenolysis selectivity without a switch over to a preferential a/3 interaction, Pt-Cu ensembles having obviously an intrinsic hydrogenolysis ability, due, perhaps, to their hydrogen sorption ability [46]. The same explanation was offered for the effect of VOCI [46] which also can bind hydrogen. 10. Conclusion In conclusion, it is clear that many questions about the nature of active sites on metal catalysts still remain unanswered. Probe reactions can provide a very valuable in situ method of characterising real supported catalysts. Moreover, 2,2-dimethylbutane, because it can be adsorbed in a variety of different modes can be a very sensitive probe of the surface chemistry of metal catalysts. One important remaining question is how exactly to separate the influence of the chemical identity of the support from that of metal particle size. Indeed, platinum catalysts with rather similar (high) dispersion can have isomerisation selectivities from ca. 5 to 60% (Table 9). The scatter of data points was, indeed, rather large when particle size effects on platinum have been discussed and when results were obtained when platinum was supported on silica or alumina. Considering the rather large differences between EUROPr-1 and EURopr-3, platinum on different supports may not be directly comparable. Recent results indicate that various pretreatments (reduction temperature, etc., see Section 8) may represent an additional factor influencing selectivity values considerably. The presence of minute amounts of additives may also have a crucial influence (see the effects of carbon, chlorine, water, etc., discussed above). These may create an as yet unspecified electronic influence on the metal proper [ 21,48,63 ] which may manifest itself e.g., as the irregular catalytic activity of sites at the metal-support phase boundary (`adlineation effect' [ 64 ] ) . The higher isomerisation selectivity of catalysts with lower metal loading, i.e., containing more `adlineation sites' (see 0.3% and 2% Pt/A1203 in Table 9) may stress the importance of these sites in isomerisation (the importance of ay', ay and a/3 interactions being similar over all these samples), as also does the possible effect of oxidative redispersion of the catalytically active metal [ 51 ] . The problem of `true' bifunctionality, namely whether there is a real interplay between metallic sites and acidic sites in their immediate vicinity affecting reaction intermediates during their sojourn on the surface, still also needs to be clarified. Conventional dispersion measurements, or other, more sophisticated surface char- 32 R. Burch, Z. Padl /Applied Catalysis A: General 114 (1994) 9-33 acterisation techniques may not provide a sufficient explanation for these problems. That is the point where the use of probe molecules, to investigate the active sites proper, may prove indispensable. Knowing the few elementary regularities of metal catalyzed reactions of 2,2-dimethylbutane, this reactant seems to be a great help in solving a number of still open questions concerning metal-hydrocarbon interactions on real catalysts.
